posts.title: Kalimbo
posts.content:
Kalimbo is an extended thumb piano/midi controller. This project is a response to research on how collage techniques, borrowed from visual artists such as Eduardo Paolozzi, can be used as a tool to explore the creative potential of uniting the disparate elements of musical performance ecologies.

Collage techniques and principals borrowed from Paolozzi’s practice have been applied to each element of this performance ecology; the instrument is assembled from found objects and juxtaposed with an arduino and sensors to become a gestural midi controller, which in turns triggers and manipulates fragments of live audio, synthesis, recordings and found sounds.

This particular ecology includes specific interrelated sound-sets, influenced by the tuning and timbre of the original instrument. However, the instrument can be used to trigger and manipulate any sound source or data within various programs using OSC messages, or the gestural control elements of the instrument can be transplanted into other instruments or projects to provide an interactive form of data navigation.

“No one arrangement is more conclusive or significant than another… the collage principal is not bound to one solution.” – Eduardo Paolozzi

This project is a response to research on how collage techniques, borrowed from visual artists such as Eduardo Paolozzi, can be used as a tool to explore the creative potential of uniting the disparate elements of musical performance ecologies. Collage techniques and principals borrowed from Paolozzi’s practice have been … Continue reading “Kalimbo”

posts.title: CoHERE Critical Archive
posts.content:
We are constructing an online visualisation of connections between research outputs for the Horizon 2020 CoHERE Project. The CoHERE project seeks to identify, understand and valorise European heritages, engaging with their socio-political and cultural significance and their potential for developing communitarian identities. CoHERE addresses an intensifying EU Crisis through a study of relations between identities and representations and performances of history. It explores the ways in which heritages can be used for division and isolation, or to find common ground and ‘encourage modern visions and uses of its past.’

 

The content visualised will include critical essays, articles, reports and literature reviews, films and audio recordings, data files, case studies and profiles of practice-based research. As well as providing a home and linking structure for this content, the CCA will unfold and evolve over time. This will allow it to register changes in thinking, contradictions and tensions, emerging areas and debates, reflections on current affairs, provocations, conjectures and forecasts related to notions of European heritage. CCA resources will be provided in various stages of the project.

 

CoHERE has received funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No 693289.

CoHERE addresses an intensifying EU Crisis through a study of relations between identities and representations and performances … Continue reading “CoHERE Critical Archive”

posts.title: Marianne Dreams
posts.content: For Seven Stories we are building an online interactive exhibition with collaborator Dan Foster Smith using AR technology. The exhibition will take the form of a narrated exploration of archival materials from the children’s author and psychoanalyst Catherine Storr.
posts.excerpt: For Seven Stories we are building an online interactive exhibition with collaborator Dan Foster Smith using AR technology. The exhibition will take the form of a narrated exploration of archival materials from the children’s author and psychoanalyst Catherine Storr.

posts.title: One Knob to Rule Them All
posts.title_plain: One Knob to Rule Them All
posts.content:
Winner of Best Paper at NIME 2016 One Knob to Rule Them All was an intensive short research project between the Culture Lab, Newcastle University, Music, Technology and Innovation Research Centre, De Montfort University and guests from Tongji University, Centre for Digital Innovation, Shanghai.

One Knob to Rule Them All is an idea presented by John Bowers in: Musical Meshworks:  From Networked Performance to Cultures of Exchange. In this article, Bowers considers an interface that is “ … a single control … inviting for a novice user but one which had unexpected built in complexity to hold the attention of an experienced user.” This research project sets to build on these initial ideas and explore related themes: These may include:

  • interpolation – sticky knob, slide, delayed response, etc.
  • reductionist approach to ‘instrument’ control/design (1 knob, 1 button, no knob, etc.)
  • post-optimal themes related to electronic objects
  • ergonomics/anti-ergonomics/un-ergonomics
  • control/lack of control
  • multi-functions
  • alternative interfaces
  • entropy
  • fractal knobbing
  • knob time
  • live coding with one knob
  • mapping
  • gender

Participants: John Bowers, Will Edmondes, Tim Shaw, Ben Freeth, John Richards, Jim Frize, Amit Patel, Neal Spowage, Sam Topley, Marinos Giannoukakis, Steve Jones, Si Waite and 李睿（Lee Ray)
posts.excerpt: Winner of Best Paper at NIME 2016 One Knob to Rule Them All was an intensive short research project between the Culture Lab, Newcastle University, Music, Technology and Innovation Research Centre, De Montfort University and guests from Tongji University, Centre for Digital Innovation, Shanghai. One Knob to Rule Them All is an idea presented by John … Continue reading “One Knob to Rule Them All”

posts.title: Crossing Borders in the Insular Middle Ages
posts.title_plain: Crossing Borders in the Insular Middle Ages
posts.content:
The research focus of the network is the exploration of literary and cultural connections across Britain, Ireland, and Iceland during the period 1250—1550, through the study of the cross-border movements of texts and vernacular translation. We term this area of literary-historical study the Insular Middle Ages, a critical concept intended to foster comparative synchronic analysis of literature produced in this region, which is approached as a distinctive cultural sphere. Drawing on the diverse expertise and training of our network members (detailed below), the project fosters the sharing of knowledge across conventional disciplinary boundaries (Celtic Studies, Scandinavian Studies, and English Studies) with a mind to a comprehensive perspective of the literary and cultural connections across the region as a whole.

We are supporting this project through the construction of a data base of literary resource which will form the basis of future scholarly work and (for us) a site of creative digital intervention.
posts.excerpt: The research focus of the network is the exploration of literary and cultural connections across Britain, Ireland, and Iceland during the period 1250—1550, through the study of the cross-border movements of texts and vernacular translation. We term this area of literary-historical study the Insular Middle Ages, a critical concept intended to foster comparative synchronic analysis … Continue reading “Crossing Borders in the Insular Middle Ages”

posts.title: Plural Heritages of Istanbul: The Case of Land Walls
posts.title_plain: Plural Heritages of Istanbul: The Case of Land Walls
posts.content:
Working with Newcastle University’s department of Media Culture and Heritage and international colleagues in Bilgi and Anadalou Universities (Turkey) we will be developing micro-locative design interventions exploring intangible cultural heritage in architectural space.

The project will develop new valorisations of the Istanbul Land (Theodosian) Walls, working with communities to co-produce both situated and web-based, public-facing digital heritage interpretation resources that reflect non-official, hitherto unauthorised understandings of the Walls and their environs. The project also builds capacity, in line with the aims of the Newton Fund, through modelling heritage management/interpretation practice, digital technologies and community engagement within the heritage sector.
The Walls are an extensive part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. They are an ancient structure, much modified in history, famously breached in the 1453 Conquest of Constantinople and now situated in a rapidly modernizing megacity. They have witnessed intercultural contact and conflict, from war to ‘gentrification’, sometimes involving involuntary displacements of communities. The Walls are officially valorized as tangible heritage, and the UNESCO statement of Outstanding Universal Value is based upon the ‘unique integration of architectural masterpieces that reflect the meeting of Europe and Asia over many centuries’. This has shortcomings related to scant engagement with, and involvement of, diverse stakeholder communities. To counter this, the project researchers will research and develop multi-perspectival narratives revalorizing the Walls in relation to different identities, experiences and attitudes to the past, proposing models for in-country urban heritage management/interpretation. This involves three interrelated uses of qualitative research into the lives, attitudes and understandings of heritage of community stakeholders: 1) to inform more responsive, ‘bottom-up’ heritage management; 2) to engage stakeholders as co-producers of public-facing heritage interpretation, in particular to produce in situ and online digital resources that valorize and present multiple stories; and 3) to rethink the Walls beyond the paradigm of tangible heritage, based on people’s ‘sense of place’.
posts.excerpt: Working with Newcastle University’s department of Media Culture and Heritage and international colleagues in Bilgi and Anadalou Universities (Turkey) we will be developing micro-locative design interventions exploring intangible cultural heritage in architectural space. The project will develop new valorisations of the Istanbul Land (Theodosian) Walls, working with communities to co-produce both situated and web-based, public-facing digital … Continue reading “Plural Heritages of Istanbul: The Case of Land Walls”

posts.title: Unbound #2: Terra Nullius
posts.content:
Unbound playfully explores alternative ways of orchestrating creative collaboration. It is inspired by a reflection on the role of prototyping in current digital artistic practice: increasingly, artists and designers working with physical computing create artefacts that cannot be black-boxed in a final material and interpretative condition. Rather, they are meant to be re-appropriated by others, continued and implemented at a later stage, or re-produced and potentially embedded in everyday life. Differently from many traditional artworks that are intended to be contemplated and to remain unique and untouched, artistic prototypes encourage further intervention and are therefore generative of new practices and social relations.

 

For the second iteration of the project, at AHRC Commons Common Ground, curator Gabi Arrigoni has collected a range of data-sets and information addressing areas of ambiguous and unclear jurisdiction, or what can be considered a global commons. They instigate an exploration of the concept of terra nullius (a territory which is not subject to sovereignty of any state) to address the question of how resources become property (and maybe vice versa). From Svalbard to the recent Liberland, examples of terra nullius have sometime represented the possibility of experimental models of governance. Similarly, outer space falls out on national sovereignty but is subject to countless bills and international regulations. Furthermore, plans are underway concerning the exploitation of its mineral resources, which obviously raise complex issues in terms of right of use, property, and transnational commons.

 

During the AHRC Commons event, the invited practitioners will creatively and freely engage with these data-sets (or more on similar topics that they might find on the web) to create a new piece of work. Half-way through the day they will exchange their artifact between each other and continue working on the colleague’s partially developed artifact. They will devise strategies to make the work shareable, understandable and suitable to be continued by somebody else.

 

This mechanism aims to explore how ideas and digital artefacts can circulate, be inspirational and generative, and support an open process of collaboration with different contributors at different stages of development. In this context individual models of creation are challenged, and creativity is affirmed as a form of improvisation and responsiveness to a set of material and social arrangements.
posts.excerpt: Unbound playfully explores alternative ways of orchestrating creative collaboration. It is inspired by a reflection on the role of prototyping in current digital artistic practice: increasingly, artists and designers working with physical computing create artefacts that cannot be black-boxed in a final material and interpretative condition. Rather, they are meant to be re-appropriated by others, … Continue reading “Unbound #2: Terra Nullius”

posts.title: Listening Through Making
posts.content:
This practice-based research explores themes of materiality, making and sonic composition and aims to provide a perspective on how knowledge can be generated through a creative engagement with material. Directly engaging with material through a process of making allows for a reciprocal relationship between maker and material to occur. When approaching material in this way, fluid forms of understanding are acquired and changed through the creative process and the result embodies the multitude of choices the designer (or maker) made throughout the making process. This method offers an alternative to static notions of knowledge perhaps more familiar to traditional western academic thinking. In my practice I am interested in a variety of materials across a number of mediums, I have actively engaged with archives, technologies, people and places as sources of creative material.

Building on existing themes set within sound studies, maker culture, anthropology and philosophy this work contributes notions of how practice-based research operates and what this method can offer to a number of different fields. Increased interest in making within academic communities is evident through the work of Tim Ingold whose research articulates makings historical significance in anthropology, archaeology, art and architecture. Ingold’s Thinking Through Making (which the title of my research acknowledges)  describes how learning takes place through a direct, responsive engagement with physical materials. Ingold also describes materials as having “perdurance”, the carrying on of material through time. Rather than thinking of things in static, object form he considers our relationship to materials to be in correspondence. In this sense, making is a means of corresponding between material flow and personal experience. This can also be related to sound design technologies and sonic art, thinking of how sound is considered through its materiality and therefore a process of understanding its properties. This is evident in the work of Pierre Schaeffer who developed theories around Musique Concrète in the mid 20th Century.
posts.excerpt: This practice-based research explores themes of materiality, making and sonic composition and aims to provide a perspective on how knowledge can be generated through a creative engagement with material. Directly engaging with material through a process of making allows for a reciprocal relationship between maker and material to occur. When approaching material in this way, fluid forms of … Continue reading “Listening Through Making”

posts.title: Loops, Layers, Lines
posts.content: The inaugural show of the Digital Cultures Studio; Loops, Layers, Lines features exhibitions and performances from Gabi Arrigoni, John Bowers, Sean Cotteril, Alexia Mellor, Riar Rizaldi, Tim Shaw, Ping Yeh-Li, Simon Bowen, Sixian Chen, Jez Coram, James Davoll, David De la Hay, Jane Dudman, Benjamin Freeth and Jiun-Shian Lin.

posts.title: Unbound
posts.content:
Unbound is a playful exploration of alternative ways of orchestrating creative collaboration. It is inspired by a reflection on the role of prototyping in current digital artistic practice: increasingly, artists and designers working with physical computing create artefacts that cannot be black-boxed in a final material and interpretative condition. Rather, they are meant to be re-appropriated by others, continued and implemented at a later stage, or re-produced and potentially embedded in everyday life. Differently from many traditional artworks that are intended to be contemplated and to remain unique and untouched, artistic prototypes encourage further intervention and are therefore generative of new practices and social relations.

Unbound invites a number of practitioners from different disciplines to work on the same artifact/artwork for one day each across one week. The starting point will be provided by the curator, and every morning after the first day, the artifact will be handed on to the next participant accompanied by a sheet filled with four parameters typical of the prototyping process.

The project investigates how prototypical creative artefacts can spark imagination and be inspirational, opening the process to different contributors at different stages of development. It also aims to explore how ideas can circulate (and be manipulated) through material objects mingling the moments of making, sharing and communicating. In this context individual models of creation are challenged, and creativity is affirmed as a form of improvisation and responsiveness to a set of material and social arrangements. Building on previous research on‘public making’(Bowers and Shaw) and‘artistic prototypes’(Arrigoni), the event can be read as a sort of fragmented hack and suggests alternative models for the working environment, for production and decision making.

Curated by Gabi Arrigoni

Participating artists: John Bowers, Sean Cotteril, Ping Yee Li, Alexia Mellor, Riar Rizaldi, Tom Schofield, Tim Shaw

It is inspired by a reflection on the role of prototyping in current digital artistic practice: increasingly, artists and designers working with physical computing create artefacts that cannot be black-boxed in a final material and interpretative condition. Rather, they are meant to be re-appropriated … Continue reading “Unbound”

posts.title: Turing Tape Music
posts.content:
A Work in Progress, Turing Tape Music performs a Media Archaeology of computer music. In Alan Turing’s description of his machine reads,

 

‘…an unlimited memory capacity obtained in the form of an infinite tape marked out into squares, on each of which a symbol could be printed. At any moment there is one symbol in the machine; it is called the scanned symbol. The machine can alter the scanned symbol, and its behavior is in part determined by that symbol, but the symbols on the tape elsewhere do not affect the behavior of the machine. However, the tape can be moved back and forth through the machine, this being one of the elementary operations of the machine. Any symbol on the tape may therefore eventually have an innings’

 

Turing Tape Music externalise the algorithmic behaviour of the machine, using a strip of LEDs representing an infinite tape of 7-bit numbers. The outcomes of the machine are used as the basis of a live-coded music performance.
posts.excerpt: A Work in Progress, Turing Tape Music performs a Media Archaeology of computer music. In Alan Turing’s description of his machine reads,   ‘…an unlimited memory capacity obtained in the form of an infinite tape marked out into squares, on each of which a symbol could be printed. At any moment there is one symbol in … Continue reading “Turing Tape Music”

tags.title: funder: Newcastle Institute for Creative Arts Practice

posts.title: data bus
posts.content:
Data Bus is a commissioned work of art and visualisation for Tyne and Wear Museums. Riders of the number 31 bus in Newcastle upon Tyne grab a ‘data snapshot’ with their smartphone which combines dominant colours from the camera with data extracted from the 2011 census. An imaginary bus route map is created using colour comparisons across the city.

In the museum, this data is combined with recorded audio along the bus route to create an installation artwork that is concerned with the tension between local specificity and generalisation in data-rich descriptions of place.

This project is indebted to the help of Sarah Cotton, Kylea Little, Richard Chippington, Xiyuan Tan and Yue Wang.

An imaginary bus route map is created using colour comparisons … Continue reading “data bus”

posts.title: Artistic Prototypes
posts.content: This research project introduces new kinds of understandings of artistic practice taking place in laboratories and engaging with the design, production and critique of technological artifacts. The recent spread of artworks based on programmed code and physical computing increased and changed the role of prototyping in the making of new media art. Indeed prototyping can be now considered as a medium in its own right. The point of departure revolves around the relationship between research and aesthetic production. The research process is found to have a specific impact on art practice, calling for artifacts understood by their makers as incomplete and expecting testing and further manipulation. These artworks are not made with museum or gallery spaces in mind, but demand different models of circulation and presentation. They are open to transformation and collaborative intervention; they tend to refuse any form of material of conceptual black-boxing. The notion of artistic prototypes emerges then to enrich the vocabulary to comprehend, evaluate and curate the outcomes of these often very transdisciplinary and collaborative practices. Research is not the only field  where prototypical artworks are developed. Often they are created for activist purposes too, as a way to critique current behaviours and attitudes (especially towards technology) and to demonstrate alternative ones are possible. The project comprises a number of curatorial projects (including workshops, exhibitions and engagement activities) that contribute to articulate and respond to a theoretical framework outlining the features and behaviours of artistic prototypes.
posts.excerpt: This research project introduces new kinds of understandings of artistic practice taking place in laboratories and engaging with the design, production and critique of technological artifacts. The recent spread of artworks based on programmed code and physical computing increased and changed the role of prototyping in the making of new media art. Indeed prototyping can be … Continue reading “Artistic Prototypes”

posts.title: Bloodaxe Books Archive Interfaces
posts.content: Bloodaxe Books is an independent publisher of contemporary poetry. Working with the School of English Language and Linguistics and Newcastle University Library’s Special Collections department we developed an innovative exploratory online interface to the publisher’s archive. Explore it here.

posts.title: The Palimpsest Machine
posts.content: The Palimpsest Machine is an installation artwork and performance that experiments with different forms of print, computer vision and audio technology to bring together medieval practices of overwriting and contemporary digital print with a Media Archaeological approach. Two dot matrix printers share a möbius strip of paper and – using various semi-improvised techniques – sample from the strip and over print onto it. For instance, late in the performance hacked Optical Character Recognition software searches for surviving traces of legible type and attempts to redact them with blocks of solid black.
posts.excerpt: The Palimpsest Machine is an installation artwork and performance that experiments with different forms of print, computer vision and audio technology to bring together medieval practices of overwriting and contemporary digital print with a Media Archaeological approach. Two dot matrix printers share a möbius strip of paper and – using various semi-improvised techniques – sample … Continue reading “The Palimpsest Machine”

tags.title: funder: Newcastle Institute for Creative Arts Practice

posts.title: Me_asure
posts.content:
Me_asure is an interactive artwork which takes measurements of facial features using contemporary face tracking technology and provides a reading of character based on 19th Century physiognomy.

Measurements such as the distance between pupils or the extent of the curve of the upper lip are taken live and compared to standards generated by a scrape of flickr photo data. From a 19th Century Manual of physiognomy (held in Newcastle University Library Special Collections) a set of ‘faculties’ of personality were identified such as ‘fondness’, ‘faithful love’ and ‘mountaineering’. These were mapped to combinations of facial features following instructions from the manual. Audience members interacting with the work were characterised by the prevalence of a set of such faculties.

Me_asure was commissioned by Syndrome and the Double Negative for FACT Liverpool as part of Liverpool Light Nights.
